The **Ramones** were an American [punk rock](/wiki/Punk_rock "Punk rock") band
that formed in the New York City neighborhood of [Forest Hills,
Queens](/wiki/Forest_Hills,_Queens "Forest Hills, Queens"), in 1974. They are
often cited as the first band to define the punk rock sound.[1][2] Despite
achieving only limited commercial success, the band was a major influence on
the 1970s punk movement in both the United States and United Kingdom.

All of the band members adopted pseudonyms ending with the surname "Ramone",
although none of them were related. They performed 2,263 concerts, touring
virtually nonstop for 22 years.[2] In 1996, after a tour with the
[Lollapalooza](/wiki/Lollapalooza "Lollapalooza") music festival, the band
[played a farewell concert](/wiki/We%27re_Outta_Here! "We're Outta Here!") and
disbanded.[3] By 2014, all four of the band's original members, lead singer
[Joey Ramone](/wiki/Joey_Ramone "Joey Ramone") (1951–2001), bass guitarist
[Dee Dee Ramone](/wiki/Dee_Dee_Ramone "Dee Dee Ramone") (1951–2002), guitarist
[Johnny Ramone](/wiki/Johnny_Ramone "Johnny Ramone") (1948–2004) and drummer
[Tommy Ramone](/wiki/Tommy_Ramone "Tommy Ramone") (1949–2014), had
died.[4][5][6][7]

Recognition of the band's importance built over the years, and they are now
mentioned in many assessments of all-time great rock music, such as number 26
in the _[Rolling Stone](/wiki/Rolling_Stone "Rolling Stone")_ magazine list of
the "[100 Greatest Artists of All
Time](/wiki/Rolling_Stone%27s_100_Greatest_Artists_of_All_Time "Rolling
Stone's 100 Greatest Artists of All Time")"[8] and number 17 in
[VH1](/wiki/VH1 "VH1")'s "100 Greatest Artists of Hard Rock".[9] In 2002, the
Ramones were ranked the second-greatest band of all time by
_[Spin](/wiki/Spin_\(magazine\) "Spin \(magazine\)")_ magazine, trailing only
[the Beatles](/wiki/The_Beatles "The Beatles").[10] On March 18, 2002, the
original four members and Tommy's replacement on drums, [Marky
Ramone](/wiki/Marky_Ramone "Marky Ramone"), were inducted into the [Rock and
Roll Hall of Fame](/wiki/Rock_and_Roll_Hall_of_Fame "Rock and Roll Hall of
Fame").[2][11] In 2011, the group was awarded a [Grammy Lifetime Achievement
Award](/wiki/Grammy_Lifetime_Achievement_Award "Grammy Lifetime Achievement
Award").[12][13]

## History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ramones&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: History")]

### Formation:
1974–1975[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ramones&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Formation: 1974–1975")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/ForestHillsHS.jpg/170px-
ForestHillsHS.jpg)](/wiki/File:ForestHillsHS.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:ForestHillsHS.jpg "Enlarge")

[Forest Hills High School](/wiki/Forest_Hills_High_School_\(New_York\) "Forest
Hills High School \(New York\)"), attended by the four original members of the
Ramones

The original members of the band met in and around the middle-class
neighborhood of [Forest Hills](/wiki/Forest_Hills,_Queens "Forest Hills,
Queens") in the New York City borough of [Queens](/wiki/Queens,_New_York
"Queens, New York"). [John Cummings](/wiki/Johnny_Ramone "Johnny Ramone") and
[Thomas Erdelyi](/wiki/Tommy_Ramone "Tommy Ramone") had both been in a high-
school [garage band](/wiki/Garage_rock "Garage rock") from 1965 to 1967 known
as the Tangerine Puppets.[14] They became friends with [Douglas
Colvin](/wiki/Dee_Dee_Ramone "Dee Dee Ramone"), who had recently moved to the
area from Germany,[15] and [Jeffrey Hyman](/wiki/Joey_Ramone "Joey Ramone"),
who was the initial lead singer of the [glam rock](/wiki/Glam_rock "Glam
rock") band [Sniper](/wiki/Sniper_\(American_band\) "Sniper \(American
band\)"), founded in 1972.[16][17]

The Ramones began taking shape in early 1974 when Cummings and Colvin invited
Hyman to join them in a band. The initial line-up featured Colvin on lead
vocals, rhythm and bass guitars, Cummings on lead guitar, and Hyman on drums.
Hyman soon switched from drums to vocals. Colvin was the first to adopt the
name "Ramone", calling himself Dee Dee Ramone. He was inspired by [Paul
McCartney](/wiki/Paul_McCartney "Paul McCartney")'s use of the pseudonym Paul
Ramon during his [Silver Beetles](/wiki/The_Quarrymen "The Quarrymen")
days.[18][19] Dee Dee convinced the other members to take on the name and came
up with the idea of calling the band the Ramones.[20] Hyman and Cummings
became Joey and Johnny Ramone, respectively.[20]

A friend of the band, Monte A. Melnick (later their tour manager), helped to
arrange rehearsal time for them at Manhattan's Performance Studios, where he
worked. Johnny's former bandmate Erdelyi was set to become their manager. Soon
after the band was formed, Dee Dee realized that he could not sing and play
his bass guitar simultaneously; with Erdelyi's encouragement, Joey became the
band's new lead singer.[18] Dee Dee would continue, however, to count off each
song's tempo with his signature rapid-fire shout of "1-2-3-4!" Joey soon
similarly realized that he could not sing and play drums simultaneously and
left the position of drummer. While auditioning prospective replacements,
Erdelyi would often take to the drums and demonstrate how to play the songs.
It became apparent that he was able to perform the group's music better than
anyone else, and he joined the band as Tommy Ramone.[21]

The Ramones played before an audience for the first time on March 30, 1974, at
Performance Studios.[2] The songs they played were very fast and very short;
most clocked in at under two minutes. Around this time, a new music scene was
emerging in New York centered on two clubs in [downtown
Manhattan](/wiki/Lower_Manhattan "Lower Manhattan")—[Max's Kansas
City](/wiki/Max%27s_Kansas_City "Max's Kansas City") and, more famously,
[CBGB](/wiki/CBGB "CBGB") (usually referred to as CBGB's). The Ramones made
their CBGB debut on August 16, 1974.[22] [Legs McNeil](/wiki/Legs_McNeil "Legs
McNeil"), who cofounded _[Punk](/wiki/Punk_\(magazine\) "Punk \(magazine\)")_
magazine the following year, later described the impact of that performance:
"They were all wearing these black leather jackets. And they counted off this
song... and it was just this wall of noise... They looked so striking. These
guys were not hippies. This was something completely new."[23]

The band swiftly became regulars at the club, playing there seventy-four times
by the end of the year. After garnering considerable attention for their
performances—which averaged about seventeen minutes from beginning to end—the
group was signed to a recording contract in late 1975 by [Seymour
Stein](/wiki/Seymour_Stein "Seymour Stein") of [Sire
Records](/wiki/Sire_Records "Sire Records"). After they were seen by Sire A&R
man [Craig Leon](/wiki/Craig_Leon "Craig Leon")[24] he brought the band to the
attention of the label. Stein's wife, [Linda Stein](/wiki/Linda_S._Stein
"Linda S. Stein"), saw the band play at Mothers; she would later co-manage
them along with [Danny Fields](/wiki/Danny_Fields "Danny Fields").[25] By this
time, the Ramones were recognized as leaders of the new scene that was
increasingly being referred to as "[punk](/wiki/Punk_rock "Punk
rock")".[26][27] The group's unusual frontman had a lot to do with their
impact. As Dee Dee explained, "All the other singers [in New York] were
copying [David Johansen](/wiki/David_Johansen "David Johansen") [of [the New
York Dolls](/wiki/The_New_York_Dolls "The New York Dolls")], who was copying
[Mick Jagger](/wiki/Mick_Jagger "Mick Jagger")... But Joey was unique, totally
unique."[28]

### Spearheading punk:
1976–1977[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ramones&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Spearheading punk: 1976–1977")]

![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg/50px-Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg.png) |  ["Blitzkrieg Bop"](/wiki/File:Ramones-Blitzkrieg_Bop.ogg "File:Ramones-Blitzkrieg Bop.ogg") ![](data:image/png,%89PNG%0D%0A%1A%0A%00%00%00%0DIHDR%00%00%00%01%00%00%00%01%08%02%00%00%00%90wS%DE%00%00%00%01sRGB%00%AE%CE%1C%E9%00%00%00%09pHYs%00%00%0B%13%00%00%0B%13%01%00%9A%9C%18%00%00%00%07tIME%07%DB%0B%0A%17%041%80%9B%E7%F2%00%00%00%19tEXtComment%00Created%20with%20GIMPW%81%0E%17%00%00%00%0CIDAT%08%D7c%60%60%60%00%00%00%04%00%01'4'%0A%00%00%00%00IEND%AEB%60%82)[](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/f/f4/Ramones-Blitzkrieg_Bop.ogg) The title of the Ramones' debut single, writes critic Steve Huey, is a "nice encapsulation of the group's aesthetic: simple, bouncy, pre-[British Invasion](/wiki/British_Invasion "British Invasion") rock & roll played at top volume and twice the speed. Blaring the same three chords for most of its duration, the song was rock at its most basic".[29]

"Wikipedia:Media help")._  
  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/2/2e/PunkMagazine.jpg/170px-
PunkMagazine.jpg)](/wiki/File:PunkMagazine.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:PunkMagazine.jpg "Enlarge")

April 1976 issue of _[Punk](/wiki/Punk_\(magazine\) "Punk \(magazine\)")_. The
cover image of Joey, by _Punk_ cofounder [John Holmstrom](/wiki/John_Holmstrom
"John Holmstrom"), was inspired by the work of comic book artist [Will
Eisner](/wiki/Will_Eisner "Will Eisner").[30] Holmstrom would go on to do
album art for _[Rocket to Russia](/wiki/Rocket_to_Russia "Rocket to Russia")_
and _[Road to Ruin](/wiki/Road_to_Ruin_\(Ramones_album\) "Road to Ruin
\(Ramones album\)")_.[31]

The Ramones recorded their debut album, _[Ramones](/wiki/Ramones_\(album\)
"Ramones \(album\)")_ , in April 1976. Of the fourteen songs on the album, the
longest, "I Don't Wanna Go Down to the Basement", barely surpassed two and a
half minutes. While the songwriting credits were shared by the entire band,
Dee Dee was the primary writer.[32] The _Ramones_ album was produced by Sire's
[Craig Leon](/wiki/Craig_Leon "Craig Leon"), with Tommy as associate producer,
on an extremely low budget of about $6,400 and released in April.[33] The now
iconic [front cover
photograph](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/b/bb/Ramones_-
_Ramones_cover.jpg "Ramones - Ramones cover.jpg") of the band was taken by
Roberta Bayley, a photographer for _[Punk](/wiki/Punk_\(magazine\) "Punk
\(magazine\)")_ magazine.[34] _Punk_ , which was largely responsible for
codifying the term for the scene emerging around CBGB, ran a cover story on
the Ramones in its third issue, the same month as the record's
release.[30][35]

The Ramones' debut LP was greeted by rock critics with glowing reviews. The
_[Village Voice](/wiki/Village_Voice "Village Voice")_ 's [Robert
Christgau](/wiki/Robert_Christgau "Robert Christgau") wrote, "I love this
record—love it—even though I know these boys flirt with images of brutality
(Nazi especially)... For me, it blows everything else off the radio".[36] In
_[Rolling Stone](/wiki/Rolling_Stone "Rolling Stone")_ , [Paul
Nelson](/wiki/Paul_Nelson_\(critic\) "Paul Nelson \(critic\)") described it as
"constructed almost entirely of rhythm tracks of an exhilarating intensity
rock & roll has not experienced since its earliest days." Characterizing the
band as "authentic American primitives whose work has to be heard to be
understood", he declared, "It is time popular music followed the other arts in
honoring its primitives."[37] _[Newsday](/wiki/Newsday "Newsday")_ 's Wayne
Robbins simply anointed the Ramones as "the best young rock 'n' roll band in
the known universe."[38]

Despite Sire's high hopes for it,[39] _Ramones_ was not a commercial success,
reaching only number 111 on the _[Billboard](/wiki/Billboard_charts "Billboard
charts")_ album chart.[40] The two singles issued from the album, "[Blitzkrieg
Bop](/wiki/Blitzkrieg_Bop "Blitzkrieg Bop")" and "I Wanna Be Your Boyfriend",
failed to chart. At the band's first major performance outside of New York, a
June date in [Youngstown, Ohio](/wiki/Youngstown,_Ohio "Youngstown, Ohio"),
members of Cleveland punk legends Frankenstein aka the [Dead
Boys](/wiki/The_Dead_Boys "The Dead Boys") were present and struck up a
friendship with the band.[41] It wasn't until they made a brief tour of
England that they began to see the fruits of their labor; a performance at the
[Roundhouse](/wiki/Roundhouse_\(venue\) "Roundhouse \(venue\)") in London on
July 4, 1976, second-billed to the [Flamin' Groovies](/wiki/Flamin%27_Groovies
"Flamin' Groovies"), organized by Linda Stein, was a resounding success.[42]
[T-Rex](/wiki/T-Rex_\(band\) "T-Rex \(band\)") leader [Marc
Bolan](/wiki/Marc_Bolan "Marc Bolan") was in attendance at the Roundhouse show
and was invited on stage.[43][44] Their Roundhouse appearance and a club date
the following night—where the band met members of the [Sex
Pistols](/wiki/Sex_Pistols "Sex Pistols") and [the Clash](/wiki/The_Clash "The
Clash")—helped galvanize the burgeoning UK punk rock scene.[4] The Flamin'
Groovies/Ramones double bill was successfully reprised at the [Roxy
Theatre](/wiki/Roxy_Theatre_\(West_Hollywood\) "Roxy Theatre \(West
Hollywood\)") in Los Angeles the following month, fueling the [punk scene
there](/wiki/Punk_rock_in_California "Punk rock in California") as well. The
Ramones were becoming an increasingly popular live act—a Toronto performance
in September energized yet another growing punk scene.[45]

Their next two albums, _[Leave Home](/wiki/Leave_Home "Leave Home")_ and
_[Rocket to Russia](/wiki/Rocket_to_Russia "Rocket to Russia")_ , were
released in 1977. Both were produced by Tommy and [Tony
Bongiovi](/wiki/Tony_Bongiovi "Tony Bongiovi"), the second cousin of [Jon Bon
Jovi](/wiki/Jon_Bon_Jovi "Jon Bon Jovi").[46] _Leave Home_ met with even less
chart success than _Ramones_ , though it did include "Pinhead", which became
one of the band's signature songs with its chanted refrain of "Gabba gabba
hey!" _Leave Home_ also included a fast-paced cover of the oldie "[California
Sun](/wiki/California_Sun "California Sun")", written by Henry Glover & Morris
Levy, and originally recorded by Joe Jones,[47] though the Ramones based their
version on the remake by the Rivieras. _Rocket to Russia_ was the band's
highest-charting album to date, reaching number 49 on the [_Billboard_
200](/wiki/Billboard_200 "Billboard 200").[48] In _Rolling Stone_ , critic
[Dave Marsh](/wiki/Dave_Marsh "Dave Marsh") called it "the best American rock
& roll of the year".[49] The album also featured the first Ramones single to
enter the _Billboard_ charts (albeit only as high as number 81): "[Sheena Is a
Punk Rocker](/wiki/Sheena_Is_a_Punk_Rocker "Sheena Is a Punk Rocker")". The
follow-up single, "Rockaway Beach", reached number 66—the highest any Ramones
single would ever reach in America. On December 31, 1977 the Ramones recorded
_[It's Alive](/wiki/It%27s_Alive_\(Ramones_album\) "It's Alive \(Ramones
album\)")_, a live concert double album, at the [Rainbow
Theatre](/wiki/Rainbow_\(London\) "Rainbow \(London\)"), London, which was
released in April 1979 (the title is a reference to the [1974 horror film of
the same name](/wiki/It%27s_Alive_\(1974_film\) "It's Alive \(1974
film\)")).[50]

### Recordings turn more pop:
1978–1983[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ramones&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Recordings turn more pop: 1978–1983")]

Tommy, tired of touring, left the band in early 1978. He continued as the
Ramones' record producer under his birth name of Erdelyi. His position as
drummer was filled by [Marc Bell](/wiki/Marky_Ramone "Marky Ramone"), who had
been a member of the early 1970s hard rock band [Dust](/wiki/Dust_\(band\)
"Dust \(band\)"), [Wayne County and the Backstreet Boys](/wiki/Jayne_County
"Jayne County"),[51] and the pioneering punk group [Richard Hell & the
Voidoids](/wiki/The_Voidoids "The Voidoids").[52] Bell became Marky Ramone.
Later that year, the band released their fourth studio album, and first with
Marky, _[Road to Ruin](/wiki/Road_to_Ruin_\(Ramones_album\) "Road to Ruin
\(Ramones album\)")_. The album, co-produced by Tommy with [Ed
Stasium](/wiki/Ed_Stasium "Ed Stasium"), included some new sounds such as
acoustic guitar, several ballads, and the band's first two recorded songs
longer than three minutes. It failed to reach the [_Billboard_ Top
100](/wiki/Billboard_Top_100 "Billboard Top 100"). However, "[I Wanna Be
Sedated](/wiki/I_Wanna_Be_Sedated "I Wanna Be Sedated")", which appeared both
on the album and as a single, would become one of the band's best-known
songs.[53] The artwork on the album's cover was done by _Punk_ magazine
cofounder [John Holmstrom](/wiki/John_Holmstrom "John Holmstrom").[54]

After the band's movie debut in [Roger Corman](/wiki/Roger_Corman "Roger
Corman")'s _[Rock'n' Roll High School](/wiki/Rock_%27n%27_Roll_High_School
"Rock 'n' Roll High School")_ (1979), renowned producer [Phil
Spector](/wiki/Phil_Spector "Phil Spector") became interested in the Ramones
and produced their 1980 album _[End of the Century](/wiki/End_of_the_Century
"End of the Century")_. During the recording sessions in Los Angeles, Spector
held Johnny at gunpoint, forcing him to repeatedly play a riff.[55] Though it
was to be the highest-charting album in the band's history—reaching number 44
in the United States and number 14 in Great Britain—Johnny made clear that he
favored the band's more aggressive punk material: "_End of the Century_ was
just watered-down Ramones. It's not the real Ramones."[56] This stance was
also conveyed by the title and track selection of the compilation album Johnny
later oversaw, _[Loud, Fast Ramones: Their Toughest
Hits](/wiki/Loud,_Fast_Ramones:_Their_Toughest_Hits "Loud, Fast Ramones: Their
Toughest Hits")_. Despite these reservations, Johnny did concede that some of
Spector's work with the band had merit, saying "It really worked when he got
to a slower song like '[Danny Says](/wiki/Danny_Says "Danny Says")'—the
production really worked tremendously. 'Rock 'N' Roll Radio' is really good.
For the harder stuff, it didn't work as well."[57] The string-laden
[Ronettes](/wiki/The_Ronettes "The Ronettes") cover "[Baby, I Love
You](/wiki/Baby,_I_Love_You "Baby, I Love You")" released as a single, became
the band's biggest hit in Great Britain, reaching number 8 on the charts.[58]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/Ramones_1983_b.jpg/220px-
Ramones_1983_b.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ramones_1983_b.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Ramones_1983_b.jpg "Enlarge")

Joey and Dee Dee Ramone in concert, 1983

_[Pleasant Dreams](/wiki/Pleasant_Dreams "Pleasant Dreams")_ , the band's
sixth album, was released in 1981. It continued the trend established by _End
of the Century_ , taking the band further from the raw punk sound of its early
records. As described by _[Trouser Press](/wiki/Trouser_Press "Trouser
Press")_ , the album, produced by [Graham Gouldman](/wiki/Graham_Gouldman
"Graham Gouldman") of UK pop act [10cc](/wiki/10cc "10cc"), moved the Ramones
"away from their pioneering minimalism into heavy metal territory".[59] Johnny
would contend in retrospect that this direction was a record company decision,
a continued futile attempt to get airplay on American radio.[1][57] While
_Pleasant Dreams_ reached number 58 on the U.S. chart, its two singles failed
to register at all.[60]

_[Subterranean Jungle](/wiki/Subterranean_Jungle "Subterranean Jungle")_ ,
produced by [Ritchie Cordell](/wiki/Ritchie_Cordell "Ritchie Cordell") and
Glen Kolotkin, was released in 1983.[61] According to _Trouser Press_ , it
brought the band "back to where they once belonged: junky '60s pop adjusted
for current tastes", which among other things meant "easing off the breakneck
rhythm that was once Ramones dogma."[59] Billy Rogers, who had performed with
[Johnny Thunders and the Heartbreakers](/wiki/The_Heartbreakers "The
Heartbreakers"), played drums on the album's second single, a cover of [the
Chambers Brothers](/wiki/The_Chambers_Brothers "The Chambers Brothers")'
"[Time Has Come Today](/wiki/Time_Has_Come_Today "Time Has Come Today")",
becoming the only song showing three different drummers: Rogers on recording,
Marky on album credits and Richie on video clip.[62] _Subterranean Jungle_
peaked at number 83 in the United States—it would be the last album by the
band to crack the _Billboard_ Top 100.[63][64] In 2002, Rhino Records released
a new version of it with seven bonus tracks.[65]

### Shuffling members:
1983–1989[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ramones&action=edit&section=5 "Edit
section: Shuffling members: 1983–1989")]

After the release of _Subterranean Jungle_ , Marky was fired from the band due
to his alcoholism.[66] He was replaced by Richard Reinhardt, who adopted the
name [Richie Ramone](/wiki/Richie_Ramone "Richie Ramone"). [Joey
Ramone](/wiki/Joey_Ramone "Joey Ramone") remarked that "[Richie] saved the
band as far as I'm concerned. He's the greatest thing to happen to the
Ramones. He put the spirit back in the band."[67] Richie is the only Ramones
drummer to sing lead vocals on Ramones songs, including "(You) Can't Say
Anything Nice" as well as the unreleased "Elevator Operator". Joey Ramone
commented, "Richie's very talented and he's very diverse... He really
strengthened the band a hundred percent because he sings backing tracks, he
sings lead, and he sings with Dee Dee's stuff. In the past, it was always just
me singing for the most part."[68] Richie was also the only drummer to be the
sole composer of Ramones songs including their hit "[Somebody Put Something in
My Drink](/wiki/Somebody_Put_Something_in_My_Drink "Somebody Put Something in
My Drink")" as well as "Smash You", "Humankind", "I'm Not Jesus", "I Know
Better Now" and "(You) Can't Say Anything Nice". Joey Ramone supported
Richie's songwriting contributions: "I encouraged Richie to write songs. I
figured it would make him feel more a part of the group, because we never let
anybody else write our songs."[69][70] Richie's composition, "Somebody Put
Something in My Drink", remained a staple in the Ramones set list until their
last show in 1996 and was included in the album _Loud, Fast Ramones: Their
Toughest Hits_.[71] The eight song bonus disc, _The Ramones Smash You: Live
'85_, is also named after Richie's composition "Smash You".

The first album the Ramones recorded with Richie was _[Too Tough to
Die](/wiki/Too_Tough_to_Die "Too Tough to Die")_ in 1984, with Tommy Erdelyi
and Ed Stasium returning as producers. The album marked a shift to something
like the band's original sound. In the description of Allmusic's [Stephen
Thomas Erlewine](/wiki/Stephen_Thomas_Erlewine "Stephen Thomas Erlewine"), the
"rhythms are back up to jackhammer speed and the songs are down to short,
terse statements."[72]

![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg/50px-Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg.png) |  ["Bonzo Goes to Bitburg"](/wiki/File:Bonzo_Goes_To_Bitburg.ogg "File:Bonzo Goes To Bitburg.ogg") ![](data:image/png,%89PNG%0D%0A%1A%0A%00%00%00%0DIHDR%00%00%00%01%00%00%00%01%08%02%00%00%00%90wS%DE%00%00%00%01sRGB%00%AE%CE%1C%E9%00%00%00%09pHYs%00%00%0B%13%00%00%0B%13%01%00%9A%9C%18%00%00%00%07tIME%07%DB%0B%0A%17%041%80%9B%E7%F2%00%00%00%19tEXtComment%00Created%20with%20GIMPW%81%0E%17%00%00%00%0CIDAT%08%D7c%60%60%60%00%00%00%04%00%01'4'%0A%00%00%00%00IEND%AEB%60%82)[](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/9/95/Bonzo_Goes_To_Bitburg.ogg) Over a "power-pop beat and melodic hooks galore", writes [David Corn](/wiki/David_Corn "David Corn"), Joey "snarls" the beginning of the refrain—"Bonzo goes to Bitburg/then goes out for a cup of tea/As I watched it on TV/somehow it really bothered me".[73] In contrast, [Salon.com](/wiki/Salon.com "Salon.com") arts editor Bill Wyman writes of "Joey's pained, pleading voice".[74]

* * *  
  
---|---  
_Problems playing this file? See[media help](/wiki/Wikipedia:Media_help
"Wikipedia:Media help")._  
  
The band's main release of 1985 was the British single "[Bonzo Goes to
Bitburg](/wiki/Bonzo_Goes_to_Bitburg "Bonzo Goes to Bitburg")"; though it was
available in the United States only as an import, it was played widely on
American college radio.[75] The song was written, primarily by Joey, in
protest of [Ronald Reagan](/wiki/Ronald_Reagan "Ronald Reagan")'s visit to a
German military cemetery, which included graves of [Waffen SS](/wiki/Waffen_SS
"Waffen SS") soldiers.[76] Retitled "My Brain Is Hanging Upside Down (Bonzo
Goes to Bitburg)", the song appeared on the band's ninth studio album,
_[Animal Boy](/wiki/Animal_Boy "Animal Boy")_ (1986). Produced by [Jean
Beauvoir](/wiki/Jean_Beauvoir "Jean Beauvoir"), formerly a member of the
[Plasmatics](/wiki/Plasmatics "Plasmatics"), the album was characterized by a
_Rolling Stone_ reviewer as "nonstop primal fuzz pop".[77] Making it his pick
for "album of the week", _New York Times_ critic [Jon
Pareles](/wiki/Jon_Pareles "Jon Pareles") wrote that the Ramones "speak up for
outcasts and disturbed individuals".[78]

The following year the band recorded their last album with Richie, _[Halfway
to Sanity](/wiki/Halfway_to_Sanity "Halfway to Sanity")._ Richie left in
August 1987, upset that after being in the band for five years, the other
members would still not give him a share of the money they made selling
T-shirts.[79] Richie was replaced by [Clem Burke](/wiki/Clem_Burke "Clem
Burke") from [Blondie](/wiki/Blondie_\(band\) "Blondie \(band\)"), which was
disbanded at the time. According to Johnny, the performances with Burke—who
adopted the name Elvis Ramone—were a disaster. He was fired after two
performances (August 28 & 29, 1987) because his drumming could not keep up
with the rest of the band.[79] In September, Marky, now clean and sober,
returned to the band.[20]

In December 1988, the Ramones recorded material for their eleventh studio
album, _[Brain Drain](/wiki/Brain_Drain_\(album\) "Brain Drain \(album\)")_ ;
co-produced by Beauvoir, Rey, and [Bill Laswell](/wiki/Bill_Laswell "Bill
Laswell"). However, the bass parts were done by Daniel Rey and [the
Dictators](/wiki/The_Dictators "The Dictators")' [Andy
Shernoff](/wiki/Andy_Shernoff "Andy Shernoff"). Dee Dee Ramone would only
record the additional vocals on the album citing that the other members of the
band (including himself) were going through personal troubles and changes to
the point where he didn't want to be in the band anymore. After the band
finished their Halfway to Sanity tour in February 1989, Dee Dee became sober
and left the band.

He was replaced by [Christopher Joseph Ward](/wiki/C._J._Ramone "C. J.
Ramone") (C.J. Ramone), who performed with the band until they disbanded. Dee
Dee initially pursued a brief career as a rapper under the name Dee Dee King.
He quickly returned to punk rock and formed several bands, in much the same
vein as the Ramones, for whom he also continued to write songs.[80]

### Final years:
1990–1996[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ramones&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: Final years: 1990–1996")]

After more than a decade and a half at Sire Records, the Ramones moved to a
new label, [Radioactive Records](/wiki/Radioactive_Records "Radioactive
Records"). Their first album for the label was 1992's _[Mondo
Bizarro](/wiki/Mondo_Bizarro "Mondo Bizarro")_ , which reunited them with
producer Ed Stasium.[81] _[Acid Eaters](/wiki/Acid_Eaters "Acid Eaters")_ ,
consisting entirely of cover songs, came out the following year.[82] In 1993,
the Ramones were featured in the animated television series _[The
Simpsons](/wiki/The_Simpsons "The Simpsons")_ , providing music and voices for
animated versions of themselves in the episode
"[Rosebud](/wiki/Rosebud_\(The_Simpsons\) "Rosebud \(The Simpsons\)")".[83]
Executive producer [David Mirkin](/wiki/David_Mirkin "David Mirkin") described
the Ramones as "gigantic, obsessive _Simpsons_ fans."

In 1995, the Ramones released _[¡Adios Amigos!](/wiki/%C2%A1Adios_Amigos!
"¡Adios Amigos!")_ , their fourteenth studio album, and announced that they
planned to disband if it was not successful.[84][85] Its sales were
unremarkable, garnering it just two weeks on the lower end of the _Billboard_
chart.[86] The band spent late 1995 on what was promoted as a farewell tour.
However, they accepted an offer to appear in the sixth
[Lollapalooza](/wiki/Lollapalooza "Lollapalooza") festival, which toured
around the United States during the following summer.[87] After the
Lollapalooza tour's conclusion, the Ramones played their final show on August
6, 1996, at the Palace in [Hollywood](/wiki/Hollywood,_Los_Angeles "Hollywood,
Los Angeles"). A recording of the concert was later released on video and CD
as _[We're Outta Here!](/wiki/We%27re_Outta_Here! "We're Outta Here!")_. In
addition to a reappearance by Dee Dee, the show featured several guests
including [Motörhead](/wiki/Mot%C3%B6rhead "Motörhead")'s [Lemmy](/wiki/Lemmy
"Lemmy"), [Pearl Jam](/wiki/Pearl_Jam "Pearl Jam")'s [Eddie
Vedder](/wiki/Eddie_Vedder "Eddie Vedder"), [Soundgarden](/wiki/Soundgarden
"Soundgarden")'s [Chris Cornell](/wiki/Chris_Cornell "Chris Cornell"),
Numskull's Ralph Foster and [Rancid](/wiki/Rancid_\(band\) "Rancid
\(band\)")'s [Tim Armstrong](/wiki/Tim_Armstrong "Tim Armstrong") and [Lars
Frederiksen](/wiki/Lars_Frederiksen "Lars Frederiksen").[3]

### Aftermath and
deaths[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ramones&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section:
Aftermath and deaths")]

On July 20, 1999, Dee Dee, Johnny, Joey, Tommy, Marky, and C.J. appeared
together at the [Virgin Megastore](/wiki/Virgin_Megastore "Virgin Megastore")
in New York City for an autograph signing. This was the last occasion on which
the original four members of the group appeared together. Joey, who had been
diagnosed with [lymphoma](/wiki/Lymphoma "Lymphoma") in 1995, died of the
illness on April 15, 2001, in New York.[4][88]

Session drummer Billy Rogers, who performed on "Time Has Come Today" from
_Subterranean Jungle_ , died from complications due to pneumonia on August 7,
2001.

On March 18, 2002, the Ramones were inducted into the [Rock and Roll Hall of
Fame](/wiki/Rock_and_Roll_Hall_of_Fame "Rock and Roll Hall of Fame"), which
specifically named Dee Dee, Johnny, Joey, Tommy, and Marky. At the ceremony,
the surviving inductees spoke on behalf of the band. Johnny spoke first,
thanking the band's fans and blessing [George W. Bush](/wiki/George_W._Bush
"George W. Bush") and his presidency. Tommy spoke next, saying how honored the
band felt, but how much it would have meant for Joey. Dee Dee humorously
congratulated and thanked himself, while Marky thanked Tommy for influencing
his drum style. [Green Day](/wiki/Green_Day "Green Day") played "Teenage
Lobotomy", "Rockaway Beach", and "[Blitzkrieg Bop](/wiki/Blitzkrieg_Bop
"Blitzkrieg Bop")" as a tribute, demonstrating the Ramones' continuing
influence on later rock musicians. The ceremony was one of Dee Dee's last
public appearances; on June 5, 2002, two months later, he was found at his
Hollywood home, dead from a heroin overdose.[5]

On November 30, 2003, New York City unveiled a sign designating East 2nd
Street at the corner of Bowery as Joey Ramone Place. The singer lived on East
2nd for a time, and the sign is near the former Bowery site of CBGB.[89] The
documentary film _[End of the Century: The Story of the
Ramones](/wiki/End_of_the_Century:_The_Story_of_the_Ramones "End of the
Century: The Story of the Ramones")_ came out in 2004. Johnny, who had been
privately suffering from prostate cancer, died on September 15, 2004 in Los
Angeles, shortly after the film's release.[6] On the same day as Johnny's
death, the world's first [Ramones Museum](/wiki/Ramones_Museum "Ramones
Museum") opened its doors to the public. Located in Berlin, Germany, the
museum features more than 300 items of memorabilia, including a pair of stage-
worn jeans from Johnny, a stage-worn glove from Joey, Marky's sneakers, and
C.J.'s stage-worn bass strap.[90]

The Ramones were inducted into the [Long Island Music Hall of
Fame](/wiki/Long_Island_Music_Hall_of_Fame "Long Island Music Hall of Fame")
in 2007.[91] That October saw the release of a DVD set containing concert
footage of the band: _[It's Alive 1974-1996](/wiki/It%27s_Alive_1974-1996
"It's Alive 1974-1996")_ includes 118 songs from 33 performances over the span
of the group's career.[92] In February 2011 the group was honored with a
[Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award](/wiki/Grammy_Lifetime_Achievement_Award
"Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award"). Drummers Tommy, Marky, and Richie
attended the ceremony.[12][13] Marky declared, "This is amazing. I never
expected this. I'm sure Johnny, Joey, and Dee Dee would never have expected
this."[12] Richie noted that it was the first time ever that all three
drummers were under the same roof, and mused that he couldn't "help thinking
that [Joey] is watching us right now with a little smile on his face behind
his rose-colored glasses."[13]

On April 30, 2014, their first album, _Ramones_ , became certified Gold by the
Recording Industry of America after selling 500,000 copies, 38 years after its
release.

[Arturo Vega](/wiki/Arturo_Vega "Arturo Vega"), creative director from their
formation in 1974 until their disbanding in 1996 and often considered the
fifth Ramone[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_], died on June 8, 2013, at the age of 65. The
final original member, Tommy Ramone, died on July 11, 2014 after a battle with
bile duct cancer.[93]

On October 30, 2016, the RAMONES WAY was unveiled at the intersection of 67th
Avenue and 110th Street in front of the main entrance of Forest Hills High
School in the borough of Queens.[94]

## Conflicts between
members[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ramones&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section:
Conflicts between members")]

There were strong tensions between Joey and Johnny, which colored much of the
Ramones' career. The pair were politically antagonistic, Joey being a
[liberal](/wiki/Liberalism_in_the_United_States "Liberalism in the United
States") and Johnny a [conservative](/wiki/Conservatism_in_the_United_States
"Conservatism in the United States"). Their personalities also clashed:
Johnny, who spent two years in military school, lived by a strict code of
self-discipline,[95] while Joey struggled with [obsessive-compulsive
disorder](/wiki/Obsessive-compulsive_disorder "Obsessive-compulsive disorder")
and alcoholism.[96][97] In the early 1980s, [Linda Ramone](/wiki/Linda_Ramone
"Linda Ramone") began a relationship with Johnny after having already been
romantically involved with Joey. Consequently, despite their continued
professional relationship, Joey and Johnny had become aloof.[6] It was not
until after Joey's death that Johnny had admitted to not calling Joey prior to
his passing, and in the documentary _End of the Century_ Johnny claimed that
Joey's death had a profound impact on him emotionally and that he was
depressed for "the whole week" after his death.[79]

Dee Dee's [bipolar disorder](/wiki/Bipolar_disorder "Bipolar disorder") and
repeated relapses into drug addiction also caused significant strains.[98]
Tommy would also leave the band after being "physically threatened by Johnny,
treated with contempt by Dee Dee, and all but ignored by Joey".[99] As new
members joined over the years, disbursement and the bands' image frequently
became matters of serious dispute.[100] The tensions among the group members
were not kept secret from the public as was heard on the [Howard
Stern](/wiki/Howard_Stern "Howard Stern") radio show in 1997, where during the
interview Marky and Joey got into a fight about their respective drinking
habits.[101]

## Style[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ramones&action=edit&section=9 "Edit
section: Style")]

### Musical style[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ramones&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Musical style")]

![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg/50px-Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg.png) |  ["Sheena Is a Punk Rocker"](/wiki/File:Ramones_Sheena.ogg "File:Ramones Sheena.ogg") ![](data:image/png,%89PNG%0D%0A%1A%0A%00%00%00%0DIHDR%00%00%00%01%00%00%00%01%08%02%00%00%00%90wS%DE%00%00%00%01sRGB%00%AE%CE%1C%E9%00%00%00%09pHYs%00%00%0B%13%00%00%0B%13%01%00%9A%9C%18%00%00%00%07tIME%07%DB%0B%0A%17%041%80%9B%E7%F2%00%00%00%19tEXtComment%00Created%20with%20GIMPW%81%0E%17%00%00%00%0CIDAT%08%D7c%60%60%60%00%00%00%04%00%01'4'%0A%00%00%00%00IEND%AEB%60%82)[](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/5/5e/Ramones_Sheena.ogg) Cultural critic Anders Johannsson uses this 1977 single as an example of how most Ramones songs "work in the same way: the same hammering on the drums, the same distorted guitars, the same howling of an extremely short text, in a simple tune with an even simpler chorus".[102]

* * *  
  
---|---  
_Problems playing this file? See[media help](/wiki/Wikipedia:Media_help
"Wikipedia:Media help")._  
  
The Ramones' loud, fast, straightforward musical style was influenced by pop
music that the band members grew up listening to in the 1950s and 1960s,
including classic rock groups such as [the Beach Boys](/wiki/The_Beach_Boys
"The Beach Boys"), [the Who](/wiki/The_Who "The Who"), [the
Beatles](/wiki/The_Beatles "The Beatles"), [the Kinks](/wiki/The_Kinks "The
Kinks"), [Led Zeppelin](/wiki/Led_Zeppelin "Led Zeppelin"), [the Rolling
Stones](/wiki/The_Rolling_Stones "The Rolling Stones") and [Creedence
Clearwater Revival](/wiki/Creedence_Clearwater_Revival "Creedence Clearwater
Revival"); [bubblegum](/wiki/Bubblegum_pop "Bubblegum pop") acts like the
[1910 Fruitgum Company](/wiki/1910_Fruitgum_Company "1910 Fruitgum Company")
and [Ohio Express](/wiki/Ohio_Express "Ohio Express"); and girl groups such as
[the Ronettes](/wiki/The_Ronettes "The Ronettes") and [the Shangri-
Las](/wiki/The_Shangri-Las "The Shangri-Las"). They also drew on the harder
rock sound of the [MC5](/wiki/MC5 "MC5"), [Black Sabbath](/wiki/Black_Sabbath
"Black Sabbath"),[103] [the Stooges](/wiki/The_Stooges "The Stooges") and the
[New York Dolls](/wiki/New_York_Dolls "New York Dolls"), now known as seminal
[protopunk](/wiki/Protopunk "Protopunk") bands.[104] The Ramones' style was in
part a reaction against the heavily produced, often bombastic music that
dominated the pop charts in the 1970s. "We decided to start our own group
because we were bored with everything we heard," Joey once explained. "In
[1974](/wiki/1974_in_music "1974 in music") everything was tenth-generation
[Elton John](/wiki/Elton_John "Elton John"), or overproduced, or just junk.
Everything was long jams, long guitar solos ... . We missed music like it used
to be."[105] [Ira Robbins](/wiki/Ira_Robbins "Ira Robbins") and Scott Isler of
_[Trouser Press](/wiki/Trouser_Press "Trouser Press")_ describe the result:

> With just four chords and one manic tempo, New York's Ramones blasted open
> the clogged arteries of mid-'70s rock, reanimating the music. Their genius
> was to recapture the short/simple aesthetic from which pop had strayed,
> adding a caustic sense of trash-culture humor and minimalist rhythm guitar
> sound.[106]

As leaders in the [punk rock](/wiki/Punk_rock "Punk rock") scene, the Ramones'
music has usually been identified with that label,[1] while some have defined
their characteristic style more specifically as [pop punk](/wiki/Pop_punk "Pop
punk")[107] and others as [power pop](/wiki/Power_pop "Power pop").[108] In
the 1980s, the band sometimes veered into [hardcore punk](/wiki/Hardcore_punk
"Hardcore punk") territory, as can be heard on _[Too Tough to
Die](/wiki/Too_Tough_to_Die "Too Tough to Die")_.[106]

On stage, the band adopted a focused approach directly intended to increase
the audience's concert experience. Johnny's instructions to C.J. when
preparing for his first live performances with the group were to play facing
the audience, to stand with the bass slung low between spread legs, and to
walk forward to the front of stage at the same time as he did. Johnny was not
a fan of guitarists who performed facing their drummer, amplifier, or other
band members.[109]

### Visual imagery[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ramones&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Visual imagery")]

The Ramones' art and visual imagery complemented the themes of their music and
performance. The band members adopted a uniform look of long hair, leather
jackets, T-shirts, torn jeans, and sneakers. This fashion emphasized
minimalism, which was a powerful influence on the New York punk scene of the
1970s and reflected the band's short, simple songs.[110] Tommy Ramone recalled
that, both musically and visually, "we were influenced by comic books, movies,
the [Andy Warhol](/wiki/Andy_Warhol "Andy Warhol") scene, and avant-garde
films. I was a big _[Mad](/wiki/Mad_\(magazine\) "Mad \(magazine\)")_ magazine
fan myself."[110]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/5/57/Ramones_logo.jpg/220px-
Ramones_logo.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ramones_logo.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Ramones_logo.jpg "Enlarge")

The band's logo, based on the [Seal of the President of the United
States](/wiki/Seal_of_the_President_of_the_United_States "Seal of the
President of the United States")

The band's logo was created by New York City artist [Arturo
Vega](/wiki/Arturo_Vega "Arturo Vega") together with the Ramones. Vega was a
longtime friend who had allowed Joey and Dee Dee to move into his loft.[111]
Vega produced the band's T-shirts, their main source of income, basing most of
the images on a black-and-white self-portrait photograph he had taken of his
American bald eagle belt buckle which had appeared on the back sleeve of the
Ramones' first album.[112] He was inspired to create the band's logo after a
trip to Washington, D.C.:

> I saw them as the ultimate all-American band. To me, they reflected the
> American character in general—an almost childish innocent aggression ... . I
> thought, 'The Great Seal of the President of the United States' would be
> perfect for the Ramones, with the eagle holding arrows—to symbolize strength
> and the aggression that would be used against whomever dares to attack
> us—and an olive branch, offered to those who want to be friendly. But we
> decided to change it a little bit. Instead of the olive branch, we had an
> apple tree branch, since the Ramones were American as apple pie. And since
> Johnny was such a baseball fanatic, we had the eagle hold a baseball bat
> instead of the [Great Seal]'s arrows.[112]

The scroll in the eagle's beak originally read "Look out below", but this was
soon changed to "Hey ho let's go" after the opening lyrics of the band's first
single, "[Blitzkrieg Bop](/wiki/Blitzkrieg_Bop "Blitzkrieg Bop")". The
arrowheads on the shield came from a design on a polyester shirt Vega had
bought. The name "Ramones" was spelled out in block capitals above the logo
using plastic stick-on letters.[25] Where the presidential emblem read "Seal
of the President of the United States" clockwise in the border around the
eagle, Vega instead placed the pseudonyms of the four band members: Johnny,
Joey, Dee Dee, and Tommy. Over the years the names in the border would change
as the band's line-up fluctuated.[113]

## Influence[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ramones&action=edit&section=12 "Edit
section: Influence")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Johnny-
Ramone_1977.jpg/170px-Johnny-Ramone_1977.jpg)](/wiki/File:Johnny-
Ramone_1977.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Johnny-Ramone_1977.jpg "Enlarge")

Johnny Ramone in concert, 1977

The Ramones had a broad and lasting influence on the development of [popular
music](/wiki/Popular_music "Popular music"). Music historian [Jon
Savage](/wiki/Jon_Savage "Jon Savage") writes of their debut album that "it
remains one of the few records that changed pop forever."[114] As described by
[AllMusic](/wiki/AllMusic "AllMusic") critic [Stephen Thomas
Erlewine](/wiki/Stephen_Thomas_Erlewine "Stephen Thomas Erlewine"), "The
band's first four albums set the blueprint for punk, especially American punk
and hardcore, for the next two decades."[115] _Trouser Press '_s Robbins and
Isler similarly wrote that the Ramones "not only spearheaded the original new
wave/punk movement, but also drew the blueprint for subsequent hardcore punk
bands".[106] Punk journalist Phil Strongman writes, "In purely _musical_
terms, the Ramones, in attempting to re-create the excitement of pre-Dolby
rock, were to cast a huge shadow—they had fused a blueprint for much of the
indie future."[26] Writing for _[Slate](/wiki/Slate_\(magazine\) "Slate
\(magazine\)")_ in 2001, [Douglas Wolk](/wiki/Douglas_Wolk "Douglas Wolk")
described the Ramones as "easily the most influential group of the last 30
years."[116]

[The Ramones' debut album](/wiki/Ramones_\(album\) "Ramones \(album\)") had an
outsized effect relative to its modest sales. According to [Generation
X](/wiki/Generation_X_\(band\) "Generation X \(band\)") bassist [Tony
James](/wiki/Tony_James "Tony James"), "Everybody went up three gears the day
they got that first Ramones album. Punk rock—that rama-lama super fast
stuff—is totally down to the Ramones. Bands were just playing in an
[MC5](/wiki/MC5 "MC5") groove until then."[117] The Ramones' two July 1976
shows, like their debut album, are seen as having a significant impact on the
style of many of the newly formed British punk acts—as one observer put it,
"instantly nearly every band speeded up".[118] The Ramones' first British
concert, at London's Roundhouse concert hall, was held on July 4, 1976, the
[United States Bicentennial](/wiki/United_States_Bicentennial "United States
Bicentennial").[119] The [Sex Pistols](/wiki/Sex_Pistols "Sex Pistols") were
playing in [Sheffield](/wiki/Sheffield "Sheffield") that evening, supported by
[the Clash](/wiki/The_Clash "The Clash"), making their public debut. The next
night, members of both bands attended the Ramones' gig at the Dingwall's club.
Ramones manager Danny Fields recalls a conversation between Johnny Ramone and
Clash bassist [Paul Simonon](/wiki/Paul_Simonon "Paul Simonon") (which he
mislocates at the Roundhouse): "Johnny asked him, 'What do you do? Are you in
a band?' Paul said, 'Well, we just rehearse. We call ourselves the Clash but
we're not good enough.' Johnny said, 'Wait till you see us—we stink, we're
lousy, we can't play. Just get out there and do it.'"[120] Another band whose
members saw the Ramones perform, [the Damned](/wiki/The_Damned_\(band\) "The
Damned \(band\)"), played their first show two days later. The central
[fanzine](/wiki/Fanzine "Fanzine") of the early UK punk scene, _[Sniffin'
Glue](/wiki/Sniffin%27_Glue "Sniffin' Glue")_, was named after the song "Now I
Wanna Sniff Some Glue", which appeared on the debut LP.[121]

Ramones concerts and recordings influenced many musicians central to the
development of [California punk](/wiki/Punk_rock_in_California "Punk rock in
California") as well, including [Greg Ginn](/wiki/Greg_Ginn "Greg Ginn") of
[Black Flag](/wiki/Black_Flag_\(band\) "Black Flag \(band\)"),[122] [Jello
Biafra](/wiki/Jello_Biafra "Jello Biafra") of the [Dead
Kennedys](/wiki/Dead_Kennedys "Dead Kennedys"),[123] [Al
Jourgensen](/wiki/Al_Jourgensen "Al Jourgensen") of
[Ministry](/wiki/Ministry_\(band\) "Ministry \(band\)"),[124] [Mike
Ness](/wiki/Mike_Ness "Mike Ness") of [Social
Distortion](/wiki/Social_Distortion "Social Distortion"),[125] [Brett
Gurewitz](/wiki/Brett_Gurewitz "Brett Gurewitz") of [Bad
Religion](/wiki/Bad_Religion "Bad Religion"),[126] and members of the
[Descendents](/wiki/Descendents "Descendents").[127] Canada's first major punk
scenes—in Toronto and in [British Columbia](/wiki/British_Columbia "British
Columbia")'s [Victoria](/wiki/Victoria,_British_Columbia "Victoria, British
Columbia") and Vancouver—were also heavily influenced by the Ramones.[45][128]
In the late 1970s, many bands emerged with musical styles deeply indebted to
the band's. There were [the Lurkers](/wiki/The_Lurkers "The Lurkers") from
England,[129] [the Undertones](/wiki/The_Undertones "The Undertones") from
Ireland,[130] [Teenage Head](/wiki/Teenage_Head_\(band\) "Teenage Head
\(band\)") from Canada,[131] and [the Zeros](/wiki/The_Zeros_\(American_band\)
"The Zeros \(American band\)")[132] and [the Dickies](/wiki/The_Dickies "The
Dickies")[133] from southern California. The seminal hardcore band [Bad
Brains](/wiki/Bad_Brains "Bad Brains") took its name from a Ramones song.[134]
The [Riverdales](/wiki/Riverdales "Riverdales") emulated the sound of the
Ramones throughout their career.[135] [Green Day](/wiki/Green_Day "Green Day")
frontman [Billie Joe Armstrong](/wiki/Billie_Joe_Armstrong "Billie Joe
Armstrong") named his son Joey in homage to Joey Ramone, and drummer [Tré
Cool](/wiki/Tr%C3%A9_Cool "Tré Cool") named his daughter Ramona.[136]

New Jersey's [horror punk](/wiki/Horror_punk "Horror punk")/[hardcore
punk](/wiki/Hardcore_punk "Hardcore punk") band the
[Misfits](/wiki/Misfits_\(band\) "Misfits \(band\)") (whose bassist [Jerry
Only](/wiki/Jerry_Only "Jerry Only") was a longtime friend of the band) were
influenced by the "Blitzkrieg" tempo of the Ramones, infusing it into their
already medium-fast tempo, [R&B](/wiki/R%26B "R&B") style of punk rock.

The Ramones also influenced musicians associated with other genres, such as
[heavy metal](/wiki/Heavy_metal_music "Heavy metal music"). Their influence on
metal gave birth to the punk-metal "fusion" genre of
[thrash](/wiki/Thrash_metal "Thrash metal"). [Metallica](/wiki/Metallica
"Metallica") guitarist [Kirk Hammett](/wiki/Kirk_Hammett "Kirk Hammett"), one
of the originators of thrash guitar, has described the importance of Johnny's
rapid-fire guitar playing style to his own musical development.[137]
[Motörhead](/wiki/Mot%C3%B6rhead "Motörhead") lead singer [Lemmy](/wiki/Lemmy
"Lemmy"), a friend of the Ramones since the late 1970s, mixed the band's "Go
Home Ann" in 1985. The members of Motörhead later composed the song
"[R.A.M.O.N.E.S.](/wiki/R.A.M.O.N.E.S. "R.A.M.O.N.E.S.")" as a tribute, and
Lemmy performed at the final Ramones concert in 1996.[138] In the realm of
[alternative rock](/wiki/Alternative_rock "Alternative rock"), the song "[53rd
and 3rd](/wiki/53rd_and_3rd "53rd and 3rd")" lent its name to a British [indie
pop](/wiki/Indie_pop "Indie pop") label cofounded by Stephen Pastel of the
Scottish band [the Pastels](/wiki/The_Pastels "The Pastels"). [Evan
Dando](/wiki/Evan_Dando "Evan Dando") of [the Lemonheads](/wiki/The_Lemonheads
"The Lemonheads"),[139] [Dave Grohl](/wiki/Dave_Grohl "Dave Grohl") of
[Nirvana](/wiki/Nirvana_\(band\) "Nirvana \(band\)") and [Foo
Fighters](/wiki/Foo_Fighters "Foo Fighters"),[121] [Mike
Portnoy](/wiki/Mike_Portnoy "Mike Portnoy") of [Dream
Theater](/wiki/Dream_Theater "Dream Theater"), [Eddie
Vedder](/wiki/Eddie_Vedder "Eddie Vedder") of [Pearl Jam](/wiki/Pearl_Jam
"Pearl Jam")[140] (who introduced the band members at their Rock and Roll Hall
of Fame induction) and [the Strokes](/wiki/The_Strokes "The Strokes")[141] are
among the many alternative rock and metal musicians who have credited the
Ramones with inspiring them.[142]

The band members were also individually influential. [Johnny
Ramone](/wiki/Johnny_Ramone "Johnny Ramone") was named one of
_[Time](/wiki/Time_\(magazine\) "Time \(magazine\)")'_s "10 Greatest Electric-
Guitar Players" in 2003.[143] That same year, he was number 16 on the "100
Greatest Guitarists of All Time" list in _[Rolling Stone](/wiki/Rolling_Stone
"Rolling Stone")_.[144]

"We think of the Ramones as a classic, iconic band," observed [Gene
Simmons](/wiki/Gene_Simmons "Gene Simmons"). "They have [one gold
record](/wiki/Ramones_\(album\) "Ramones \(album\)") to their name. They never
played arenas; couldn't sell them out. It was a failed band. It doesn't mean
they weren't great. It means the masses didn't care."[145]

[Kevin Morby](/wiki/Kevin_Morby "Kevin Morby")'s fourth album _City Music_
features the track "1234" inspired by the singer's childhood love of Ramones.
It features the lyrics "Joey, Johnny, Dee Dee, Tommy/ They were all my
friends, but they died."

### Tribute albums[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ramones&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Tribute albums")]

In April 2009, _Spin_ writer Mark Prindle observed that the Ramones had to
date "inspired a jaw-dropping 48 (at least!) full-length tribute
records."[146] The first Ramones tribute album featuring multiple performers
was released in 1991: _[Gabba Gabba Hey: A Tribute to the
Ramones](/wiki/Gabba_Gabba_Hey:_A_Tribute_to_the_Ramones "Gabba Gabba Hey: A
Tribute to the Ramones")_ includes tracks by such acts as [the Flesh
Eaters](/wiki/The_Flesh_Eaters "The Flesh Eaters"), [L7](/wiki/L7_\(band\) "L7
\(band\)"), [Mojo Nixon](/wiki/Mojo_Nixon "Mojo Nixon"), and Bad
Religion.[142] In 2001, Dee Dee made a guest appearance on one track of
_[Ramones Maniacs](/wiki/Ramones_Maniacs "Ramones Maniacs")_ , a multi-artist
cover of the entire _[Ramones Mania](/wiki/Ramones_Mania "Ramones Mania")_
compilation album. _[The Song Ramones the
Same](/wiki/The_Song_Ramones_the_Same "The Song Ramones the Same")_ , which
came out the following year, includes performances by [the
Dictators](/wiki/The_Dictators "The Dictators"), who were part of the early
New York punk scene, and [Wayne Kramer](/wiki/Wayne_Kramer_\(guitarist\)
"Wayne Kramer \(guitarist\)"), guitarist for the influential protopunk band
[MC5](/wiki/MC5 "MC5"). _[We're a Happy Family: A Tribute to
Ramones](/wiki/We%27re_a_Happy_Family:_A_Tribute_to_Ramones "We're a Happy
Family: A Tribute to Ramones")_, released in 2003, features performers such as
[Rancid](/wiki/Rancid_\(band\) "Rancid \(band\)"), [Green Day](/wiki/Green_Day
"Green Day"), [Metallica](/wiki/Metallica "Metallica"),
[Kiss](/wiki/Kiss_\(band\) "Kiss \(band\)"), [the
Offspring](/wiki/The_Offspring "The Offspring"), [Red Hot Chili
Peppers](/wiki/Red_Hot_Chili_Peppers "Red Hot Chili Peppers"), [U2](/wiki/U2
"U2"), and [Rob Zombie](/wiki/Rob_Zombie "Rob Zombie") (who also did the album
cover artwork).[147] Also some other famous bands recorded tribute songs.
Motörhead's Phil Campbell tells in Jari-Pekka Laitio-Ramone's book _Ramones:
Soundtrack Of Our Lives_ : "We did a cover of Rockaway Beach with me on
backing vocals, which was quite enjoyable. When Johnny Ramone heard it, he
refused to put it on the tribute album. Lemmy and I thought we did a good
version."[148]

Punk bands such as [Screeching Weasel](/wiki/Screeching_Weasel "Screeching
Weasel"), [the Vindictives](/wiki/The_Vindictives "The Vindictives"), [the
Queers](/wiki/The_Queers "The Queers"), [Parasites](/wiki/Parasites_\(band\)
"Parasites \(band\)"), [the Mr. T Experience](/wiki/The_Mr._T_Experience "The
Mr. T Experience"), [Boris the Sprinkler](/wiki/Boris_the_Sprinkler "Boris the
Sprinkler"), [Beatnik
Termites](/w/index.php?title=Beatnik_Termites&action=edit&redlink=1 "Beatnik
Termites \(page does not exist\)"), Tip Toppers, [Jon Cougar Concentration
Camp](/wiki/Jon_Cougar_Concentration_Camp "Jon Cougar Concentration Camp"),
[McRackins](/wiki/McRackins "McRackins"), and Kobanes have recorded cover
versions of entire Ramones albums— _Ramones_ , _Leave Home_ , _Rocket to
Russia_ , _It 's Alive_, _Road to Ruin_ , _End of the Century_ , _Pleasant
Dreams_ , _Subterranean Jungle_ , two versions of _Too Tough to Die_ , and
_Halfway To Sanity_ respectively.[146][149] [The
Huntingtons](/wiki/The_Huntingtons "The Huntingtons")' _[File Under
Ramones](/wiki/File_Under_Ramones "File Under Ramones")_ consists of Ramones
covers from across the band's history.[150]

[Shonen Knife](/wiki/Shonen_Knife "Shonen Knife"), an all-woman trio band from
Osaka, Japan, was formed in 1981 as a direct result of founder-lead singer-
guitarist [Naoko Yamano](/wiki/Naoko_Yamano "Naoko Yamano")'s instant
infatuation with the music of the Ramones. In 2012, to observe the band's 30th
anniversary, Shonen Knife released _[Osaka Ramones](/wiki/Osaka_Ramones "Osaka
Ramones")_ , which featured thirteen Ramones songs covered by the band.[151]

There are also many other tribute albums listed on Jari-Pekka Laitio-Ramone's
site.[152] [[1]](http://www.ramonesheaven.com)

## Band members[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ramones&action=edit&section=14 "Edit
section: Band members")]

  * [Joey Ramone](/wiki/Joey_Ramone "Joey Ramone") (Jeffrey Hyman) – drums (1974); lead vocals (1974–1996; died 2001)
  * [Johnny Ramone](/wiki/Johnny_Ramone "Johnny Ramone") (John Cummings) – guitar (1974–1996; died 2004)
  * [Dee Dee Ramone](/wiki/Dee_Dee_Ramone "Dee Dee Ramone") (Douglas Colvin) – bass guitar, vocals (1974–1989; died 2002)
  * [Tommy Ramone](/wiki/Tommy_Ramone "Tommy Ramone") (Thomas Erdelyi) – drums (1974–1978; died 2014)
  * [Marky Ramone](/wiki/Marky_Ramone "Marky Ramone") (Marc Bell) – drums (1978–1983, 1987–1996)
  * [Richie Ramone](/wiki/Richie_Ramone "Richie Ramone") (Richard Reinhardt) – drums, backing vocals (1983–1987)
  * [C. J. Ramone](/wiki/C._J._Ramone "C. J. Ramone") (Christopher Joseph Ward) – bass guitar, vocals (1989–1996)
  * [Elvis Ramone](/wiki/Elvis_Ramone "Elvis Ramone") (Clem Burke) – drums (1987)
